sen.j: 土御門 定通（つちみかど さだみち・源 定通、文治4年（1188年） - 宝治元年9月28日 (旧暦)（1247年10月28日※）は、鎌倉時代の公卿。
sen.e: Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO (1188 – October 28, 1247#) was a court noble in the Kamakura Period (Japan).
Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO (1188 – October 28, 1247#) was a court noble in the Kamakura Period (Japan).
Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO (1188 – November 4, 1247#) was a court noble in the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: ユリウス→グレゴリオ暦に修正、Kamakura periodとし、(Japan)を削除

sen.j: 源通親の4男で早世した長兄・源通宗の養子としてその後を継いだ。
sen.e: He was MINAMOTO no Michichika's fourth son and succeeded him as the foster child of his eldest son, MINAMOTO no Michimune.
He was MINAMOTO no Michichika's fourth son and succeeded him as the foster child of his eldest son, MINAMOTO no Michimune.
He was MINAMOTO no Michichika's fourth son and succeeded him as the foster child of his eldest son, MINAMOTO no Michimune.

sen.j: 母は刑部卿藤原範兼の娘・藤原範子（後鳥羽天皇の乳母）、姉は承明門院源在子（土御門天皇の母）。
sen.e: His mother was Gyobukyo (Minister of Justice)FUJIWARA no Norikane's daughter, FUJIWARA no Noriko (nurse to Emperor Gotoba), and his sister was Shomeimoin MINAMOTO no Zaishi (Emperor Tsuchimikado's mother).

His mother was Gyobukyo (Minister of Justice)FUJIWARA no Norikane's daughter, FUJIWARA no Noriko (nurse to Emperor Gotoba), and his sister was Shomeimoin MINAMOTO no Zaishi (Emperor Tsuchimikado's mother).

His mother was Gyobukyo (Minister of Justice) FUJIWARA no Norikane's daughter, FUJIWARA no Noriko (nurse to Emperor Gotoba), and his sister was Shomeimoin MINAMOTO no Zaishi (Emperor Tsuchimikado's mother).

sen.j: 妻は鎌倉幕府2代執権北条義時の女（六波羅探題・連署北条重時の同母妹）。
sen.e: His wife was the daughter of the second regent of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) Yoshitoki HOJO, who was the sister sharing the same mother of Rokuhara tandai (agents of the Kamakura bakufu stationed in Rokuhara, Kyoto) Rensho (assistant of the regent) Shigetoki HOJO.

His wife was the daughter of the second regent of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) Yoshitoki HOJO, who was the sister sharing the same mother of Rokuhara tandai (agents of the Kamakura bakufu stationed in Rokuhara, Kyoto) Rensho (assistant of the regent) Shigetoki HOJO.

His wife was the daughter of the second regent of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) Yoshitoki HOJO, who was the sister sharing the same mother of Rokuhara tandai (agents of the Kamakura bakufu stationed in Rokuhara, Kyoto) Rensho (assistant of the regent) Shigetoki HOJO.

sen.j: 後土御門内大臣と号した。
sen.e: He was called Gotsuchimikado Naidaijin.
He was called Gotsuchimikado Naidaijin.
He was called Gotsuchimikado Naidaijin.

sen.j: 村上源氏系土御門家の祖とされている。
sen.e: He is considered the founder of the Tsuchimikado family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan).
He is considered the founder of the Tsuchimikado family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan).
He is considered the founder of the Tsuchimikado family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: ※…ただし実際の死去日は公式発表の2日前の9月26日 (旧暦)（10月26日）であったとされている。
sen.e: #-His actual date of death is said to be October 26, two days before the official announcement).
#-His actual date of death is said to be October 26, two days before the official announcement).
#-His actual date of death is said to be November 2, two days before the official announcement).

sen.j: 生まれた翌年には叙爵を受け、14歳で父の論功によって正四位下となった。
sen.e: He received a rank the year after he was born and was appointed to Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) due to his father's achievements. He rose quickly through the ranks, being appointed to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) the next year and Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) two years later.

He received a rank the year after he was born and was appointed to Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) due to his father's achievements. He rose quickly through the ranks, being appointed to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) the next year and Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) two years later.
He received a rank the year after he was born and was appointed to Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) at the age of 14 due to his father's achievements.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「14歳で」を訳出

sen.j: 翌年には従三位、更に2年後には正三位という破格の出世を遂げた。
sen.e: He rose quickly through the ranks, being appointed to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) the next year and Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) two years later.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: この間に異母兄・通宗の養子となる。
sen.e: During this time, he became his half-brother Michimune's foster child.
During this time, he became his half-brother Michimune's foster child.
During this time, he became his half-brother Michimune's foster child.

sen.j: 通宗の娘・源通子は土御門天皇の典侍として邦仁王（後の後嵯峨天皇）を生んでいる。
sen.e: Michimune's daughter MINAMOTO no Tsushi was Emperor Tsuchimikado's Naishi no suke (maid of honor) and gave birth to Prince Kunihito (later Emperor Gosaga).
Michimune's daughter MINAMOTO no Tsushi was Emperor Tsuchimikado's Naishi no suke (maid of honor) and gave birth to Prince Kunihito (later Emperor Gosaga).
Michimune's daughter MINAMOTO no Tsushi was Emperor Tsuchimikado's Naishi no suke (maid of honor) and gave birth to Prince Kunihito (later Emperor Gosaga).

sen.j: 実の姉である承明門院の別当として後鳥羽院院政の中枢に入り、承元3年（1209年）に権中納言、建暦元年（1211年）に従二位、建保2年（1214年）に正二位、同6年（1218年）に権大納言と順調に出世した。
sen.e: He participated in the core of retired Emperor Gotoba's Office as his sister, Shomeimoin's Steward, and was promoted to Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor) in 1209, Junii (Junior Second Rank) in 1211, Shonii (Senior Second Rank) in 1214 and Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor) in 1218.

He participated in the core of retired Emperor Gotoba's Office as his sister, Shomeimoin's Steward, and was promoted to Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor) in 1209, Junii (Junior Second Rank) in 1211, Shonii (Senior Second Rank) in 1214 and Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor) in 1218.

He participated in the core of the Retired Emperor Gotoba's Office as his sister, Shomeimoin's Steward, and was promoted to Gon Chunagon (provisional vice-councilor of state) in 1209, Junii (Junior Second Rank) in 1211, Shonii (Senior Second Rank) in 1214 and Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state) in 1218.
sen.cmt: retired Emperor Gotoba's→the Retired Emperor Gotoba'sとし、Gon Chunagon、 Gon Dainagon→統一表記に修正

sen.j: その一方で、鎌倉幕府の実力者とはいえ家柄からすれば遥かに格下の北条氏から妻を迎えるなど、武家政権との関係を強めていった。
sen.e: On the other hand, he strengthened ties with the buke government by marrying a wife from the Hojo clan, who were top administrators in the Kamakura bakufu but much lower in family class.
On the other hand, he strengthened ties with the buke government by marrying a wife from the Hojo clan, who were top administrators in the Kamakura bakufu but much lower in family class.
On the other hand, he strengthened ties with the buke government by marrying a wife from the Hojo clan, who were top administrators in the Kamakura bakufu but much lower in family class.

sen.j: その運命が急転するのは、承久3年（1221年）に発生した承久の変である。
sen.e: His destiny changed radically because of the Jokyu Disturbance in 1221.
His destiny changed radically because of the Jokyu Disturbance in 1221.
His destiny changed radically because of the Jokyu Disturbance in 1221.

sen.j: 定通は直接的には関与しなかったものの、後鳥羽院政の関係者として失脚した。
sen.e: Sadamichi was not directly involved in the incident but lost his position as a related person to the office of retired Emperor Gotoba. On top of this, his nephew, the retired Emperor Tsuchimikado was exiled and the empress, his sister-in-law, Tsushi, died of disease, leaving him without his political base.

Sadamichi was not directly involved in the incident but lost his position as a related person to the office of retired Emperor Gotoba. On top of this, his nephew, the retired Emperor Tsuchimikado was exiled and the empress, his sister-in-law, Tsushi, died of disease, leaving him without his political base.
Sadamichi was not directly involved in the incident but lost his position as a related person to the office of the Retired Emperor Gotoba.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処the Retired Emperor Gotobaとしました。

sen.j: その上に甥の土御門上皇の流刑、更にはその妃である義妹・通子の病死など、定通はその政治的基盤を失ってしまった。
sen.e: On top of this, his nephew, the Retired Emperor Tsuchimikado was exiled and the empress, his sister-in-law, Tsushi, died of disease, leaving him without his political base.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処the Retired Emperor Tsuchimikadoとしました。

sen.j: その後、北条氏との縁戚関係により復権して嘉禎2年（1236年）には内大臣となったものの、政治的な影響力は失われており、ただ宮廷的には忘れられた存在となった承明門院と邦仁王の後見人としての存在でしかなかった。
sen.e: Later, he returned to power through his ties with the Hojo clan, and although he became Naidaijin (Minister of the Center) in 1236, he had already lost political influence and was only the guardian of Shomeimoin and Prince Kunihito, who had become forgotten within the court.

Later, he returned to power through his ties with the Hojo clan, and although he became Naidaijin (Minister of the Center) in 1236, he had already lost political influence and was only the guardian of Shomeimoin and Prince Kunihito, who had become forgotten within the court.

Later, he returned to power through his ties with the Hojo clan, and although he became Naidaijin (Minister of the Center) in 1236, he had already lost political influence and was only the guardian of Shomeimoin and Prince Kunihito, who had become forgotten within the court.

sen.j: そんな中で安貞元年（1227年）、定通が「殺生禁断」の地である洛南・吉祥院前の川でで家人達と鮎釣りを楽しんだことから、同院に所属する神人たちと乱闘になると言う事件を起こした。
sen.e: In such a situation, in 1227, Sadamichi was enjoying river fishing with his vassals in the Rakunan (south of Kyoto) near Kissho-in Temple, which had a prohibition on killing, when an incident involving a fight with the monks affiliated with the temple arose.

In such a situation, in 1227, Sadamichi was enjoying river fishing with his vassals in the Rakunan (south of Kyoto) near Kissho-in Temple, which had a prohibition on killing living things, when an incident arose involving a fight with the monks affiliated with the temple.

In such a situation, in 1227, Sadamichi was enjoying river fishing with his vassals in the Rakunan (south of Kyoto) near Kissho-in Temple, which had a prohibition on killing living things, when an incident arose involving a fight with the monks affiliated with the temple.

sen.j: 関白近衛家実が当時正二位大納言であった定通の責任を追及しようとしたところ、定通は当時の六波羅探題北条泰時（定通の義兄）が事情を知らずに同じ場所で釣りをした際には、神人達は武士である泰時を責めなかったのに、公卿である自分が責められるのは納得がいかないと反論し、『我もまた武士なり』と言って、逆に神人達の処断を迫ったという。
sen.e: When Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) Iezane KONOE tried to press charges on Sadamichi, who was Shonii (Senior Second Rank) Dainagon at that time, Sadamichimade a rebuttal that it was not fair that the monks accused himself, a court noble, when the present Rokuharatandai Yasutoki HOJO (Sadamichi's brother-in-law) had fished at the same place without knowing about the prohibition and the monks did not complain about the bushi Yasutoki, and demanded punishment of the monks in stead by saying "I am a bushi as well".

When Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) Iezane KONOE tried to press charges on Sadamichi, who was Shonii (Senior Second Rank) Dainagon at that time, Sadamichi made a rebuttal, saying that it was not fair that the monks accused himself, a court noble, when the present Rokuharatandai Yasutoki HOJO (Sadamichi's brother-in-law) had fished at the same place without knowing about the prohibition and the monks did not complain about the bushi Yasutoki, and demanded punishment of the monks in stead by saying "I am a bushi as well".

When Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) Iezane KONOE tried to press charges on Sadamichi, who was Shonii (Senior Second Rank) Dainagon (chief councilor of state) at that time, Sadamichi made a rebuttal, saying that it was not fair that the monks accused himself, a court noble, when the present Rokuhara tandai Yasutoki HOJO (Sadamichi's brother-in-law) had fished at the same place without knowing about the prohibition and the monks did not complain about the bushi Yasutoki, and demanded punishment of the monks in stead by saying "I am a bushi as well."
sen.cmt: Dainagonの補足追加、前出の表記に合わせRokuharatandai→Rokuhara tandaiとし、クォーテーションを半角に修正、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: この当時は実力で処断権を有する者を広く「武士」と称する用法があった事に加えて、承久の変後、武士に対して卑屈に成り下がった（定通自身も含めた）公家社会に対する痛烈な皮肉であると考えられている。
sen.e: There was a usage of "Bushi" for someone who had the right to punish with power, and this also was a sarcastic comment towards the aristocracy (including Sadamichi) who had become obsequious to the bushi class.

The term "Bushi" was sometimes used to refer to someone who had the right to punish with power, and this also was a sarcastic comment towards the aristocracy (including Sadamichi) who had become ubiquitous to the bushi class.

The term 'Bushi' was sometimes used to refer to someone who had the right to punish with power, and this also was a sarcastic comment towards the aristocracy (including Sadamichi) who had become ubiquitous to the bushi class.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションをシングル・半角に修正

sen.j: だが、仁治3年（1242年）四条天皇が急死すると、定通は密使を鎌倉に派遣して義理の兄に当たる執権・北条泰時に邦仁王の天皇擁立を働きかけた。
sen.e: However, when Emperor Shijo suddenly died in 1242, Sadamichi sent a secret messenger to Kamakura for the Regent Yasutoki HOJO who was his brother-in-law and worked towards the ascension of Prince Kunihito

However, when Emperor Shijo suddenly died in 1242, Sadamichi sent a secret messenger to Kamakura for the Regent Yasutoki HOJO who was his brother-in-law and worked towards the ascension of Prince Kunihito

However, when Emperor Shijo suddenly died in 1242, Sadamichi sent a secret messenger to Kamakura for the Regent Yasutoki HOJO who was his brother-in-law and worked towards the ascension of Prince Kunihito.

sen.j: 泰時もこの提案に乗って東使安達義景を派遣して定通と図って邦仁王を新天皇（後嵯峨天皇）として即位させたのである。
sen.e: Yasutoki agreed to this plan and sent the Toshi (messenger from the Kamakura bakufu to the Imperial Court in Kyoto) Yoshikage ADACHI to work with Sadamichi to allow Prince Kunihito (Emperor Gosaga) to ascend the throne.

Yasutoki agreed to this plan and sent the Toshi (messenger from the Kamakura bakufu to the Imperial Court in Kyoto) Yoshikage ADACHI to work with Sadamichi to allow Prince Kunihito (Emperor Gosaga) to ascend the throne.

Yasutoki agreed to this plan and sent the Toshi (messenger from the Kamakura bakufu to the Imperial Court in Kyoto) Yoshikage ADACHI to work with Sadamichi to allow Prince Kunihito (Emperor Gosaga) to ascend the throne.

sen.j: その後、後嵯峨天皇が親政を行ったこともあり、定通は官職には無かったものの、新天皇の後見人として権勢を振るって九条道家や二条良実と権勢を競った。
sen.e: Since Emperor Gosaga took charge of administration, even though Sadamichi had no official court position, he held power as the guardian of the new emperor and battled with Michiie KUJO and Yoshizane NIJO over power.

Since Emperor Gosaga took charge of administration, even though Sadamichi had no official court position, he held power as the guardian of the new emperor and battled with Michiie KUJO and Yoshizane NIJO over power.

Since Emperor Gosaga took charge of administration, even though Sadamichi had no official court position, he held power as the guardian of the new emperor and battled with Michiie KUJO and Yoshizane NIJO over power.

sen.j: 一方、幕府とも強調して朝廷改革や顕徳院の諡号を後鳥羽院という追号に改める（その背景については諸説ある）などの政策を進め、「末世の才卿」・「高才博覧の人」と評された。
sen.e: On the other hand, he worked with the bakufu to start court reforms and changed the posthumous Buddhist name of Kentoku-in in to Toba-in (various theories exist about the reason for this change), leading to the evaluation as a "talented noble of the end of the world" and "talented and well-read person".

On the other hand, he worked with the bakufu to start court reforms and changed the posthumous Buddhist name of Kentoku-in in to Toba-in (various theories exist about the reason for this change), leading to the evaluation as a "talented noble of the end of the world" and "talented and well-read person".

On the other hand, he worked with the bakufu to start court reforms and changed the posthumous Buddhist name of Kentokuin in to Tobain (various theories exist about the reason for this change), leading to the evaluation as a 'talented noble of the end of the world' and 'talented and well-read person.'
sen.cmt: Kentoku-in→Kentokuin、Toba-in→Tobainとし、クォーテーションをシングル・半角に修正、ピリオドの位置を移動
